templateAssets.content:
COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL


The lower-division prerequisites for the Celtic Studies major are usually taken at UC Berkeley upon transfer. These include two semesters of lower-division language and Celtic Studies 70 "The World of the Celts."


The elementary and intermediate first-year language sequences are started during the student’s first Fall semester at Berkeley. The required 3-semester language sequence can be completed in the two years following admission. Celtic Studies 70 is also taken the first Fall semester.


Once admitted, students who have a prior background in their proposed target language (modern Irish or Welsh) may be required to take a language proficiency test or to consult with the department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level.


Prerequisites for this major are not offered at California community colleges; however, students may be admitted to the Celtic Studies major without the 3 prerequisites as it is possible to complete all requirements for this major upon admission to UC Berkeley.


Prerequisites include:

Two first-year language courses in either modern Irish (Celtic Studies 15 and 85) or modern Welsh (Celtic Studies 16 and 86) to be started during the student’s first Fall semester at Berkeley. The required 3-semester language sequence can be completed in the two years following admission.


Celtic Studies 70 (The World of the Celts) to be taken the first Fall semester at Berkeley.


Once admitted, students who have a prior knowledge of a Celtic language may be required to take a language proficiency test or consult with the department language program coordinator for placement in the correct language course level. Students with prior knowledge of a Celtic language may apply for credit by examination.

The major in Celtic Studies is designed to give students both a broad understanding of the place of Celtic languages and cultures in the world and a firm grounding in one or more of the Celtic languages with an innovative linkage of language and literature-in-translation courses intended to allow students maximum flexibility in pursuing their programs in addition to cultural studies courses in mythology, folklore, historical studies, and Medieval studies.


In addition to three semesters of language study, students will be required to organize their major coursework with reference to one other methodological or disciplinary area chosen from Anthropology, History, Comparative Literature, Linguistics, Medieval Studies, History, Scandinavian, or another related language, literature, or cultural studies course.


For more information on this major:

The Program in Celtic Studies

https://celtic.berkeley.edu/
